text: An iPhone gets a periscope camera

text: An iPhone gets USB-C

notes:
• Seems inevitable but it might be a bit ahead of its time.
  • Ungraded: might just be the Pro phones, to advertise the improved transfer speeds.

text: An iPhone Pro with Apple Pencil support, 2 Apple Pencils
full-pick-text: An iPhone Pro with Apple Pencil support, 2 Apple Pencils
notes:
• "2 Apple Pencils: the standard and a short one that supports the iPhone and iPad mini"
  • During grading, Federico proposes what will become Risky Picks, including 2 points for correct picks and losing a point for being wrong, as Myke describes how he wanted to go big with this pick.

• Exact names weren't the main goal of this pick. The pick intended to convey that the existing iPhone X would drop from the lineup, but both sizes of 8 and 7 would stick around.
  • The SE being dropped as well wasn't enough to make the pick wrong, apparently.

text: MagSafe is updated to support 20 watt charging or higher, but a new puck is required

text: The iPhone 15 Pro Max/Ultra weighs within 10% of the iPhone 14 Pro Max's weight
full-pick-text: The iPhone 15 Pro Max/Ultra weighs within 10% of the iPhone 14 Pro Max's weight
notes: • "The new phone will need to be between 228g - 264g, as the 14 Pro Max weighs 240g" was what was written down, but those numbers are off (there was some shuffling between 5% and 10% when debating this as a Risky pick). Ultimately it did end up being within 10%.

text: The iPhone 7S and 7S+ will look like the 7 and 7+, not this edge to edge unicorn phone that has been rumored
full-pick-text: The iPhone 7S and 7S+ will look like the 7 and 7+, not this edge to edge unicorn phone that has been rumored
notes:
• This was deemed correct during grading, allowing for the "7S" actually being named the 8.
  • During grading, Myke wondered if Stephen had been thinking that there would be a phone with the traditional design, or if he was thinking that there would be no "unicorn" phone at all. Of course, it is impossible to read his mind, but in the original pick, Stephen seems to imply that it will just be the "7S".

notes: • Grading for this was tricky, but Stephen discovered that the Apple Accessory Design Guidelines indicate that the notch got very slightly smaller, by millimeters, mostly due to the switch from LCD to OLED in the iPhone 12. The consensus is that it's a technical victory but not an honorable one.

text: The only iPhones seen on stage will be the ones we already know about
full-pick-text: The only iPhones seen on stage will be the ones we already know about
notes: • This seems to have been a sub-bullet point to the previous pick originally, but was forcibly upgraded to a full pick by Myke during grading. (Again, this "game" wasn't even supposed to be a competition originally.)

text: The two Pro phones will have different camera features

notes: • It is agreed not to quibble too much about the name "Pro" if there ends up being something like an Ultra phone.

text: There is a new system for changing the colors of icons on the home screen
full-pick-text: There is a new system for changing the colors of icons on the home screen

text: There will be 3 cameras on the high end phones
full-pick-text: There will be 3 cameras on the high end phones
notes: • Ungraded: "the cameras will be ultrawide, 'the camera', and telephoto"

text: There will be a bigger iPhone X style phone, but it will not have an OLED screen
full-pick-text: There will be a bigger iPhone X style phone, but it will not have an OLED screen
notes: • The iPhone XR saved Myke here, as the XS Max was OLED which he didn't think would be possible for such a big display.

text: There will be a setting to disable the higher refresh rate in at least one of the new iPhones
full-pick-text: There will be a setting to disable the higher refresh rate in at least one of the new iPhones
notes:
• Was originally just a pick about a new, as-yet-unannounced iOS 15 feature, but the hosts suspected that was another reuse.
  • In retrospect, this was a tricky pick to grade because how would we know the day after the event? Federico provides some insider information indicating that the setting does exist, but can it be said to have "come true", as the rule states, without proof? The meaning of truth itself is debated, perhaps a philosophical high point for the Rickies. The point is ultimately granted, with the understanding that in the future, the rules will be amended to clarify that picks must be publicly verifiable to earn points.

text: There will be a system filter for "always-on display" in Focus
full-pick-text: There will be a system filter for "always-on display" in Focus
notes: • Deemed incorrect because it wasn't mentioned and there was no way to find out at the time of grading. This was in fact the correct decision, as it was not present in iOS 16 originally. The feature did eventually arrive in iOS 16.4, so this pick was just a bit early.

text: There will be no iPhone 14 with a 5.4" display
full-pick-text: There will be no iPhone 14 with a 5.4" display
notes: • AKA the iPhone mini.

text: There will not be an iPhone 15 mini
full-pick-text: There will not be an iPhone 15 mini

text: There won't be a mini iPhone in the iPhone 14 family
full-pick-text: There won't be a mini iPhone in the iPhone 14 family
notes: • Federico basically steals one of Myke's ongoing annual picks, which is allowed by the rules.

text: We see at least one new Dynamic Island feature
full-pick-text: We see at least one new Dynamic Island feature

text: You will be able to control which data types show on the always-on lock screen
full-pick-text: You will be able to control which data types show on the always-on lock screen
notes:
• Similar to the privacy controls that the always-on Apple Watch has for complications
  • This could have been a feature at the time, but there was no way to know at the time of grading. With the OS now released, we know that it was not present after all.
